org.gerstner.oauth2android.token
Class TokenTypeDefinition

java.lang.Object
  org.gerstner.oauth2android.token.TokenTypeDefinition
Direct Known Subclasses:
BearerTokenTypeDefinition, DefaultTokenTypeDefinition, MacTokenTypeDefinition
public abstract class TokenTypeDefinition
extends java.lang.Object

TokenTypeDefinition serves as a configuration class to define attributes of different kinds of tokens.
The OAuth 2.0 protokoll allows to be extended with different types of tokens. two types are implemented: the bearer and the MAC type. Bearer Tokens are very rudemental and only have most common, basic token attributes as there are: the token String itself, a lifetime and if needed a scope. The MAC Tokens however have a more complex handling. In addition to the basic attributes they hold a token secret wich is used in combination with a current timestamp and a randomly generated String to create a signature and encrypt the messages. Regarding the differences in token implementation this class is used to simplify the definition of different token types

Author:
Christoph Gerstner
See Also:
BearerToken, BearerTokenTypeDefinition, MacToken, MacTokenTypeDefinition

Constructor Detail

TokenTypeDefinition

public TokenTypeDefinition()
Method Detail

getName

public abstract java.lang.String getName()
The name or identification of the Type of the tokens. It is especially used in the authorization request header field to signal the server the use of this token type. A header could look like this:
Authorization: BEARER jncy789jmsnJl0Dk
where BEARER is the name of the token type used for this example

Returns:

getHttpAuthenticationScheme

public abstract java.lang.String getHttpAuthenticationScheme()
Used in the HTTP Authorization Header. For example a bearer token uses Authorization: BEARER to signal the server which token type to expect. MAC token use Authorization: MAC where MAC or BEARER is the name of the HTTP Authentication Scheme.

Returns:
String authentication scheme used in the HTTP-Authorization Header

getAdditionalTokenParameters

public abstract java.util.List<java.lang.String> getAdditionalTokenParameters()
Returns:

requestProtectedResource

public abstract java.lang.String requestProtectedResource(Token token,
                                                          Client client,
                                                          Server server,
                                                          java.lang.String resourceEndpoint,
                                                          java.lang.String body)
Constructs the Presentation of the token and the authorization.
Where some token types, as the bearer token, only require the token String itself, others like the MAC token type expect more parameters in this header field.
When defining a new token type, it is important to know how the token should present the authorization in the request. Either it is within the HTTP-Authorization Header or in the HTTP body itself. A server is supposed to support both but only one should be used at a time.

Examples:
Bearer-Token (within the HTTP-AUthorization Header):

Authorization: Bearer 09jk578khs62ldg

where "Authorization" is the header title, "BEARER" the authentication scheme and "09jk578khs62ldg" (the token string) is the actual Authorization Header Field.

MAC-Token (within the HTTP-AUthorization Header):
Authorization: MACid // the token id, e.g. 09jk578khs62ldg
timestamp // timestamp of the requests creation, e.g. 137131204
issuer // issuer of the token, e.g. tokens.example.com:443
nonce // a random string
bodyhash // the optional request payload body hash
mac // the calculated request mac

Parameters:
token - containing token specific parameters
client - containing all parameters of the clint
server -
resourceEndpoint - actual url where the request is directed to
Returns:

getEmptyToken

public abstract Token getEmptyToken()
Returns a new, empty token of the corresponding token type.

Returns:
new Token of the corresponding type to this definition

getAuthorizedHttpGet

public abstract HttpGet getAuthorizedHttpGet(java.util.List<NameValuePair> additionalParameter,
                                             java.lang.String requestUri,
                                             Server server,
                                             Client client,
                                             boolean useHeader)
                                      throws InvalidTokenTypeException
To make an authorized request for a protected resource using GET, this method includes all authorization parameters according to the specification of the Access Tokens type.
It is possible to include additional (non OAuth) parameters in the request, that will be transformed according to the token type specification. For example parameters pointing to the resources this request targets.
The requestURI should point to the requests endpoint, according to the service providers API specification. It does not have to include the complete host URL, since this is already defined in the Server Object.
Typically, the authorization gets included in the Authorization Request Header, since some token types don't support other authorization methods. If however, the service provider is not able to accept Authorization Request Headers (wich according to the OAuth specification, he MUST be able to) or the client is not able to manipulate the Request Headers (Android clients should be able to) or if there are other circumstances, the authorization may be included in the uri itself.

Example:

 List myList = new List();          // list with additional parameter (could be the resources)
      myList.add("a","1");          // example parameter a=1
      myList.add("b","4");          // example parameter b=4

 String requestUri = "/request";    // the whole url would be: www.example.com/request
 boolean useHeader = true;          // use the http header for authorization

  // to request the protected resource using myServer and myClient get the HttpGet object
 HttpGet myRequest = getAuthorizedHttpGet( myList, requestUri, myServer, myClient, useHeader );

  // finally to execute the request
 HttpClient myClient = new HttpDefaultClient();
 myClient.execute( myRequest );

Parameters:
additionalParameter - List of additional, non-OAuth parameters, that should be included in the request
requestUri -
server -
client -
useHeader - boolean set true, to use Http Authorization Header, false otherwise
Returns:
Throws:
InvalidTokenTypeException

getAuthorizedHttpDelete

getAuthorizedHttpPost
